description.plain:
Kevin Jerome Gilyard aka Kevin Gates was born February 5, 1986, in New Orleans, Louisiana but grew up in Baton Rouge. He began his career in 2006 as an artist on Dead Game Records.

Following a short stint in prison, in 2011, Kevin created BWA (Bread Winner’s Association), which is partnered with Atlantic Records. He lives with his wife, Dreka Gates, and now his two children Khaza and Islah, which he named his hit album of 2016.

songs.title: 2 Phones

description.plain:
Kevin Gates is a busy man so he needs two phones—to keep his drug work separate from his personal life.

“2 Phones” was released on November 5, 2015, serving as the fifth single from Gates' debut studio album Islah. It made it to number 17 on the US Billboard 100, the first time Gates had ever cracked the top 20, and, as of October 2016, his highest charting track. It also made into the Canadian top 100. It’s since been certified double platinum, with 2 million+ sales in the US alone.

The song’s accompanying music video premiered on January 1, 2016 on Kevin’s YouTube account. It was directed by Jon J, who previously directed the music videos for Gates' “Kno One” and “Really Really.”

songs.title: Really Really

description.plain:
Kevin Gates tells us how he’s really ‘bout that life. For those doubting and hating on him, Gates instinctively responds with one answer: “really really.”

“Really Really” is the fourth single from Gates' debut album, Islah. An official video was released in December 2015, and has amassed 175 million views as of December 2017.

description.plain:
Kevin hustles relentlessly as he works to achieve success in his life, and this track is clearly a testament to that.  He grinds around the clock, takes no breaks and doesn’t need time to sleep as, you guessed it, he don’t get tired.

“I Don’t Get Tired” (#IDGT) is Gates' most popular catchphrase, which he popularized through Instagram vlogs.

songs.title: Imagine That

description.plain:
In this song Kevin Gates talks about his struggles, before he was famous.
He then talks about how his life has changed since he got famous. He is living lavishly.
The intro he is talking to his kids, and wife, telling them to be strong while he is in jail serving his 2 year sentence.

description.plain: Gates explained this track is spoken from the perspective of a rapper transitioning from the streets to the fame. songs.title: Hard For

description.plain:
Featuring the classic lines “You the only one that my dick could get hard for,” Gates details his mistrust of love and explains why he’s so scared of commitment.

He told DJ Smallz that he wrote the track in prison, and detailed here how he found the right beat to match his lyrics.

This is Gates' first time releasing a “soft rock” type of song. In an interview with Complex, Gates claimed he was sick of rapping and intended to sing more. He also claimed he’s made more rock oriented songs in the past:

I just haven’t released them for fear of maybe it’s not time. But fuck that, I’mma let ’em fly. "

songs.title: Kno One

description.plain:
Although Gates is most well known for his tough image, here he drops a surprising crooner for the ladies.

This is one of many songs claimed to be produced by Cali The Producer. He lists this song on the front of his website, as he attempts to claim fame for another track he supposedly helped produce.

  Today, he unleashed “Kno One,” a colorful revenge fantasy that finds him describing in vivid detail all the dirty things he might do to a fellow dog. Buoyant, radio-ready production comes courtesy of Cali The Producer."

Despite this, there is substantial evidence of him being a fraud, as explained in detail in Steven J. Horowitz’s article here.

songs.title: Pride

description.plain:
Gates' image is one of a hardened street personality, but he delves into just how difficult it can be spending time behind bars, away from loved ones, family, and friends.

The track recieved a video in February 2016, and on the first day alone he managed 50,000 views. As of Octboer 2016 it has 25 million hits on Youtube.

description.plain:
“Out The Mud” is a typically soulful Kevin Gates joint, and is accompanied by ping-ponging production.



“Out The Mud” tells of Gates' rise from the South to nationwide recognition. His use of “mud” to describe his Southern beginnings.

songs.title: The Prayer

description.plain:
This is the second song on Murder for Hire 2, and according to Hot New Hip Hop, the song represents the “extent of experimentation"on the mixtape. The Louisiana rapper has a lot going on on this record. He invokes his tough guy Luca Brasi persona that he honed on previous mixtapes (The Luca Brasi Story and Luca Brasi 2.) At the same time, he raps about religion and Instagram beefs.

As the name of the song suggests, the song has a religious overtone. Gates talks about how his God has his body so he can live without having to worry about much other than what he needs to do to succeed. Gates is Muslim and the song includes a prayer from the first chapter of the Quran.

He also speaks on the Internet and how if you say you’re keeping it real, then you shouldn’t be on Twitter or Instagram with that false confidence those bits and bytes give.

songs.full_title: Find You Again by Kevin Gates
songs.title: Find You Again

description.plain:
In October of 2016 Kevin was sentenced to 180 days in jail which translates to almost 6 months. A year later he was sentenced to 30 months in a Illinois correctional facility for gun charges that occurred four years before in 2013. Although he was released on parole in January of 2018, the song is about how he was forced to be apart from, presumably, his wife, Dreka Gates, because he was in two different prisons in the span of almost a year.



Gates talks about this briefly in the Genius video where he breaks down the meaning of his song “Push It”.

https://genius.com/videos/Kevin-gates-breaks-down-the-meaning-of-push-it

songs.title: Plug Daughter

description.plain: Plug Daughter  is the 5th track off Kevin Gates' 2014 album Luca Brasi 2: Gangsta Grillz. It is the prequel  to Plug Daughter 2, another song by Gates which is featured on his 2021 album, Only The Generals, Pt. II. The chorus was transferred to Plug Daughter 2, and is the same on both songs. This track highlights all the aspects of drug dealing, including the extreme measures that must be taken when illegally importing and exporting drugs across the globe. A plug is someone who supplies various types of drugs to large amounts of people. In this case Gates' is saying that he in relations with the plug’s daughter in order to get more involved in his plug’s business of dealing drugs.

songs.title: Tomorrow

description.plain: Kevin Gates is touring for the second leg of his #IDGT tour, and, keeping his tagline alive, he’s been consistently dropping new music while on the road. After giving us the more melancholy “Kno One” a few weeks ago, he brings the energy back up on his latest release “Tomorrow.” This is the Baton Rouge rapper in his element, in the vein of “Don’t Know” and “Out the Mud.” Gates delivers a strong hook, with quick-flowing rhymes about street life and lessons as well as a brief touch up on dealing with depression as he does in other songs.
